Let $z$ be a complex number such that
\[|z^2 + 4| = |z(z + 2i)|.\]Find the smallest possible value of $|z + i|.$
inference:
Since
\begin{align*}
|z^2 + 4|^2 &= |z(z + 2i)|^2\\
|z|^4 + 8|z|^2 + 16 &= |z|^4 + 4|z|^2 \cdot |z + 2i|^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad |z + 2i|^2 &= 4\\
\Rightarrow\qquad |z + 2i| &= 2.
\end{align*}
Thus,
\begin{align*}
|z + i|^2 &= |(z + i) - (2i)|^2\\
&= |z - i|^2\\
&= |z|^2 + 1 - 2|z||i|\\
&= |z|^2 + 1 - 2|z|\cdot 1\\
&= (|z| - 1)^2.
\end{align*}
Since $|z + i| \ge 0$, we have $|z + i| = |z - 1|$. Therefore, the smallest possible value of $|z + i|$ is $\boxed{1}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$. I hope it is correct.
